# TRANSCRIPT 001 \- GUARDIAN INVESTIGATOR (GI) FIREW

# CLASSIFICATION: ULTRAVIOLET

# \[OFFICIAL RECORD \- PERSONAL TESTIMONY\]

They came at dawn. 

Just before prime trading period, my debt relief plan and their chances of global nuclear exchange exploded simultaneously (no thanks to Koga). 

That's what happens when you use the wrong guy for the wrong job. Low tactical awareness. They have no idea when to back away and put you in similar predicament.

Zero four thirty nine is when the duty call came in. Sleep wasn't an issue because I was already up on the day‚Äôs trades. Way up. However, even with AI assistance the numbers were in decline. So that shrill light from the phone was a blessing.

The dog fur cigarette-funked cab ride to an undisclosed location to retrieve a hidden key under a white van‚Äôs  wheelwell took ten minutes longer than it should have. By the time I stood on the beach, the first blast of dawn had broken the water, bringing those ships battling waves nearer.

Before going over the facts of the case again, I thought of everything I missed upon their successful incursion. Ultimate evil gripped ancient coral bricks of old Oki in apparition shadow.

Soon simple pleasures of this former paradise would be gone. Probably no more goopy spicy good tofu on a wooden spoon, the glassy crunch of coral bones underfoot on scattered beaches, seaweed like so many shredded green plastic skins strewn along coarse sand, or hermit crabs lugging spiral shells, under dejected Pandanus trees bearing false fruits; all was in peril thanks to our late action. What would Raquel say? Would she be ok?

That morning, as soon as I situated myself, I saw them. A fleet. Sliding under a steel sky on a previously glass sea, boats of several sizes, willingly fortified, with instruments of war aimed at menacing angles appearing like hardened urchins ready to bleed any hapless intruder.

Torii Beach seemed to shake before rising to early orange illumination. 

What would it be like if the horizon came to life? I'd always wondered. Now loose imagination ceded to rigid reality.

I raised the Steiners to eye-level. Magnification 3x at a shooter‚Äôs stance. Clear as Kin Bay following deep sea fishing, they were there. Vessels in v‚Äôed formation mobilized, massive and formidable \- absolute maritime madness.

Then the wind picked, causing my shirt to flap with that rapid whip whip whirl. That was the sign a new era had begun.

‚ÄúAre you seeing this?‚Äù

KOGA: Affirmative. 

‚ÄúYou didn't catch it. No hints or nothing.‚Äù

KOGA: My mistake is yours.

‚ÄúNo kidding.‚Äù

There was no one on the beach so early \- which was a good thing. Though I was sure the bases were already entering a rare posture.

Soon the ‚ÄúI told you sos‚Äù would come in clandestine form from gov agencies or clad in patriotic chestbeating from red wardog territory. They'd called it for years and now here we were.

Some time (longer than I can remember, but I don't know how long I'm ashamed to say) passed before I thought to bolt for my vehicle. But for a second more I stayed a spectator to the coming calamity. My mind raced with the classified intel that had crossed my desk: weather control? Tech that had been available for decades used in ways too fantastic to believe, they'd said. Not fantastic enough, apparently.

KOGA: Clouds like that don‚Äôt gather on their own. CAPCLOUD has been activated.

‚ÄúNo shit.‚Äù

I executed a stumbling turn while stowing my binos. The movement was anti-tarantellic, but enough to get me moving.

‚ÄúCan you start the car?‚Äù

KOGA: Only if your hands do it for me.

‚ÄúYou're worthless.‚Äù

KOGA: I am not worth less than this junk-able piece of shit you call a car.

‚ÄúHeh, true.‚Äù

Even though the ships still were quite a distance from the island, their shadows crept cold on my back. I felt them. They'd become bigger since I last checked. I didn't care to look to see how much. The atmosphere too took on brier patch prickly air. Unnatural cloud formations gathered with impossible speed. Something new was happening. Another warning sign captured by KOGA, missed by me.

I dashed a few clicks to my car. Beside it, foot arches aching, I ripped the front door open, slammed myself behind the wheel, shut the door, then rustled fast under my duty bag to find my phone.

Three ‚Äòno seatbelt‚Äô tones beeped before being squashed to silence by foreign naval approach.

I heard the pat-tap of raindrops hitting the roof. The sound cascade was like popcorn bursting in a microwave, at first countable, but quickly made innumerable. Typical wishy-washy Ê≤ñÁ∏Ñ weather appearing as is if coughed from the ocean below. All normal. But this time raindrops, black as wok-scrubbed dishwater, splattered then soaked the streaked windscreen. That wasn't normal. This was sent. By what? Unknown.

KOGA: Black rain? Can't say I've seen anything like it.

‚ÄúShh quiet\!‚Äù

Through pinging soot-rain, I strained toward the ocean \- then saw the flag. Flap, flap, snap, it must have been going way out there. I had to squint, but I could see it clearer then. It didn't matter.

Everybody knew who it was. Rippling red really contrasts against violet-blue expanse easy, even with passing blankets of cement clouds in the air.

The question I had was: why now? What changed? Who fucked up? 

That's when a siren blared from somewhere. An old claxon (Army undermaintained) that hadn't been used since U.S. occupation days. Words. Loud, air-checked incomprehensible, came from the Big Voice in the usual garbled manner. I didn't need to know what they were saying, to feel a thrust of violence in my veins.

KOGA: That‚Äôs not the usual broadcast. I‚Äôd translate but honestly, the tone says it all.

‚ÄúYou keep quiet. You blew your chance, now it's on me.‚Äù

I punched in the emergency protocol code \- the one they'd mocked me for establishing \- and waited for the SKOM (Space Knowledge Ops Manager and unofficial most valuable employee) to pick up. Seven rings. Eight. Someone needs to be fired, I thought.

"Command."

"This is Guardian Investigator Firew. Authorization Echo-Lima-Victor-Four-Niner. Chinese landing forces approaching Torii Beach. Weather anomalies consistent with CAPCLOUD. Possible delta-level incursion." My speech was barbed wire, freshly strung.

KOGA: That voice of yours‚Äîsteel and smoke. I archived it. Not for the record. For her. You know who I mean.

A pause. "Understood. Standby for orders."

I almost laughed. Standby. As if we had time.

‚ÄúImmediate recall. Come in, now\!‚Äù

‚ÄúGoing\!‚Äù

Next thing, I'm crunching sand and blowing dirt behind my tires. Pummeling precipitation makes it worse, while wipers work at car-shaking cadence at opening an arch of view to the road ahead. I'm taking serpentine turns up land as fast as my little Jimny can fly. The ground quaked (at least it seemed to) under the overworked engine, beneath the darkening wind.

Up, up, over the metallic chunk chunk of the gate‚Äôs speed spikes, under the red torii gate and into gridlock traffic, I mashed the pedal, but soon quit. Ahead, all cars were frozen. Every vehicle operator‚Äôs neck craned skyward, feet on brakes.

KOGA: Everyone‚Äôs looking up now. Funny how people only believe in the sky when it threatens to fall.

Then the duty phone buzzed. Priority message from Detco: "USSFDOA ACTIVE INVESTIGATION INITIATED. LOCATE ASSET 'RYU' IMMEDIATELY. FILE RECONSTRUCTION AUTHORIZED."

With that brief phone call, this became my case. The one I'd predicted. I was told: You‚Äôll be lead on this case. Comb through this mess to find out how we landed at war‚Äôs doorstep once again.

These were black choppers ‚Äì four in diamond formation. No flags or insignias, ready for clandestine ops. Judging by my alt, they flew low: perhaps half a km (though I‚Äôm unsure). Though CJ inherited a significant sum from his father, the financial stability and incentives provided by the CIA could offer him additional motivation. The security and resources available through the agency might appeal to someone who has lived a life of ascetic discomfort and uncertainty.

CJ's extensive travels and willingness to immerse himself in different cultures indicate a thirst for adventure and new experiences. The dynamic and unpredictable nature of intelligence work might satisfy his craving for excitement and challenge, motivating him to engage with the CIA.

# PHOTOGRAPH \#001 \- ‚ÄúSHISA PYRAMID‚Äù

![A group of colorful Shisa statues in front of a mountain - Ishigaki Island, Okinawa, Japan - 2022][image1]

**Photographic Analysis‚ÄîYoneko Yaki Kobo Shisa Farm, Ishigaki Island, Okinawa**

A towering mass of *shisa*‚Äîguardian lion-dogs of Okinawan folklore‚Äîrises from the green earth like a riot of frozen motion. Layered atop one another in a chaotic, yet deliberate formation, these creatures bear exaggerated grins, bulging eyes, and clawed hands, each captured mid-gesture as if animated by an unseen force. Some appear jovial, others mischievous, a few bordering on unsettling in their expressions.

At the base, stout figures anchor the structure, their thick limbs planted firmly in the earth. They are the foundation, their wide mouths open in either laughter or warning. As the tower ascends, the figures become more varied‚Äîsome bearing ornate masks, others with wild, cartoonish features. At its peak, a crowned or horned figure stands triumphant, adorned in an elaborate headdress, its mouth agape in silent declaration.

The texture of the figures is rough. The surface appears aged however, vibrantly painted in reds, yellows, blues, and whites. The colored coat has settled into the ridges, giving depth to the swirling, secret hypnotic patterns that spiral across their bodies. The entire scene feels at once playful and watchful, like a clogged parade of guardian spirits.

Beyond, the jungle presses close. Hairy foliage and steep mountain inclines provide a dramatic backdrop, as if nature itself acknowledges the presence of these sentinels. Scattered throughout the area, more *shisa* figures linger guerilla among the trees, standing in small clusters, watching. A stone bench rests at the edge of the clearing, invitingly out of place amidst the vibrant, chaotic energy of the scene.

**Investigator Notes‚ÄîCultural Context & Observations**

* **Site Identification:** *Yoneko Yaki Kobo Shisa Farm*, Ishigaki Island, Okinawa, Japan: a known ceramic workshop and display site for Okinawan *shisa*, which are traditionally believed to ward off evil spirits.

* **Structure Composition:** Fired ceramic, locally crafted. Art style is intentionally exaggerated, blending folklore with modern artistic interpretation.

* **Symbolic Significance:** *Shisa* are deeply ingrained in Okinawan culture, placed at gates, rooftops, and entrances for protection. Their presence here in such numbers suggests a large-scale guardian role, possibly tied to local traditions or the artistic vision of unknown creators.

* **Atmospheric Influence:** While rooted in folklore, the sheer scale and arrangement of the figures creates a unique psychological impact‚Äîranging from amusement to unease depending on the observer‚Äôs perspective.

* **Local Notes:** While artistic in nature, the site retains a sense of mysticism due to the *shisa*‚Äôs traditional role. It is unclear whether visitors view the installation purely as art or if some still regard it with spiritual reverence.

**RECOMMENDATION:** No direct anomalies detected‚Äîsite is a known artistic and cultural landmark. However, the psychological impact of the sheer volume of *shisa* figures warrants further study, particularly in how local beliefs influence the perception of the site. **Safe for visitation but remains a curious cultural and aesthetic experience.**

**Connection to air anomalies?**

**Unknown.**

# WITNESS STATEMENT SHARLA KINJO \[RECORDED\]

Imagine you could see into the next room. What‚Äôs there? A near-empty pen desk, fingerprint smudged laptop, maybe a memoryful TV? Foresight captures the border blur of the, this kinda field of, or state of, the space ‚Äì a shot snapped of reality. Then you pull them out, one by one pinched index and thumb at a time to pluck them over to you. After all, it‚Äôs your head, you can fill it with anything you want. And when it comes to this, you‚Äôll want as many things as possible decorating walls previously barren. Remembering (always) the ‚Äútarget.‚Äù Grasping, holding, *feeling* it as if it were a delicate shatterable orb in soapy hands. Sorry if I‚Äôm being dramatic, the whales are singing again, that had me a bit distracted.

Yes, I‚Äôm a marine biologist in training. Oki has been the best place for it, much better than where I started. Salt stamped air floating ribbon breezes with that always hovering wet scent is perfect ‚Äì keeps me calm, grants focus. I grew up up north in Osaka enclosed by grey and a ground colored river: a single stagnant line of water splitting the city. Attacked with honking and dinning day and night, I knew I had to leave. Acceptance at OIST ferried me out for good. Here‚Äôs much better.

What does this have to do with the Ishigaki Incident? I apologize, but I just wanted to give you some context for how and why I ended up down there at all. This might sound crazy, but it was a dream that got me to go.

Once you start seeing (and paying attention to) that ‚Äúworld in-between‚Äù, when the unseen needs release, it‚Äôs typewriting: no back space to erase the marks. Was that too abstract? Again, sorry if it was, but the out-of-sight fascinates me. I always think ‚Äúwhat happens when I look away?‚Äù Does it behave differently with eyes on or off? Does it transform in the dark? Does, do estimated instruments document its change? Does it even exist at all? Or was it only what I wanted to see when it had unimpeded attention? I think about these all the time. That‚Äôs what got me to study the ocean. Over 70% (approximately 71%) of this planet is water, that‚Äôs about 7/10ths undiscovered mystery to mine. If I didn‚Äôt look, would it disappear? I had to find out.

So the process was simple. You have the ‚Äútarget‚Äù (what you want to see) and your tools, but there‚Äôs no science involved at this point. No bridled plankton nets, GO black Niskin bottles, dredge nor trawl, telemetric followers, or zodiac to crack the waves aside as you might pierce a knife through paper. Just pure *feeling*. Intuition is the only engaged instrument.

You can imagine, this was torture for me as a scientist. How could you measure mean? That was a cruel thought I had when wanting to assess our impact on wonderful wavy expanse.  But when I got past the safety of numbers, that‚Äôs when the process started to work. Even you could do it right now (if you wanted to) everybody can.

It‚Äôs the ‚Äútarget‚Äù I‚Äôm thinking about, that and anything associated with it ‚Äì tightness in shoulder and stomach, mistimed breaths, impulse to write or sketch a haphazard scribble in the form of an object ‚Äì real, abstruse, or not ‚Äì are all clues. Hot and cold, am I getting close? You just have to *feel* it. Then from there you start to get a picture.

Once you‚Äôve pincered enough objects from next door, or below, or from inside ‚Äì then it‚Äôs time to identify. If you‚Äôre lucky, you solve the puzzle ‚Äì guess what, you‚Äôre right?

First time I did it, I was way off. Stuck intuition, like a hooked knit needle told me pen when it was a striped key-lime marker, but I‚Äôve gotten much better with practice. Practicing feeling, that‚Äôs all it is, not very hard.

That‚Äôs why Ishigaki was different. This was no experiment. The ‚Äútarget‚Äù was real. Ever had one of those dreams that was as so real you didn‚Äôt even know you were living a dream? The diamond drones came to me a week before, during a surprise chilly winded winter day. Planetarium stars pinned to the inner round of black sphere appeared like an upsidedown bowl above me. Below? Turtle,

These people are fanatics, I swear\! The things they do to with fortunes far less than they can conceive ruin everything, fake everything. Nothing, absolutely nothing can be believed that comes from their filthy mouths.

You know what and whom I speak, they‚Äôre at it again ‚Äì forcing this shrinking aged figure you once knew who stood so proudly, to scram madly forlornly, a wet whisker-bent cat shuddering in the rain. Embarrassing, how they go about this shit\! I‚Äôm done, I swear (this time I mean it).

You know I tried to turn it in in order to retire? Yes, I finally got the courage to do it. Aren‚Äôt you proud? 30 years in the murk and mud of these sweltering bureaucratic backwoods ‚Äì a third too many when I think about it ‚Äì has bled me pale. And all for what? A a miserable monthly credit delivered via BoJ \[Bank of Japan\] ACH to my account. Meaningless\! They think I did this for the money? They think I spoiled fooling myself around to become scrotumless pensioner while you or carebot wipes my ass in some home for those rolling toward the grave?

Bullshit nonsense\! But you know this. I‚Äôm simply airing these complaints to you ‚Äì no ‚Äì more to myself, or maybe even to God, who knows. All I know is nobody cares anymore ‚Äì this impending war proves it. Our country values an odd decentralized conformity; millions of variable-volted bulbs sharing a grid no one cares to appreciate or maintain. Objects, things, material-citizens ‚Äì that‚Äôs what we are to them, I think. To them, we stopped being people long ago. For me, I feel I can‚Äôt even guess myself what it must be to live the life of a human being anymore. For mine has been a life of much shame.

I used to blame Mama, much like you probably blame me now (a fact which I understand and never resented you for). Early on, she taught me fanged love, the kind that releases warmed outflows with every taste stinging, unsparing acts of ardored clenching you could never escape. I never wanted to, until the day it burned so bad I had to fly away from her vampiric jaws. After a time, even well after I‚Äôd joined up growing into my own man, those wolf jaws tormented me ‚Äì then like a fool, I went and passed it on to you with the same inattention. Direct blood or not, blood is blood; for that I apologize. Shame\! Shame\!

Shame this email, although shorter than most, has to be written in these perilous times. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm going so long, I have no idea if connectivity will remain stable or for how long we‚Äôll be able to rely on seized fiber to stay in touch. We may have to resort to mail snails. I hear they still run, but deliver more dangerous parcels (mostly in secret or at night when patrols a sparce).

Anyway, Turtle, how are you holding up? √áa va ?

How‚Äôs research? The sea? Spare this crumbling old man a few scraps of your life and time (please). Any young men you‚Äôre interested in? Or, young ladies? (I‚Äôm not so closet-minded but I understand your generation has a broader definition of love that I can get behind, but will probably never ‚Äì deep in my heart ‚Äì understand or appreciate.)

Whatever the circumstances of your life, tell me. You can talk to me anytime and I‚Äôll respond as my overwork allows. But I must urge you do it promptly. Because those Chinky Chinese are up to their usual schemes: first they made defilements all around our islands, invading, commandeering, smothering soft power a until we gasp for air; now they‚Äôre planning something new. 

You know I can‚Äôt say exactly what, how, when, or where, but you‚Äôre smart enough to arrange the picture pieces on your own. They‚Äôre building up, fortifying enclosures, running red streams over skies and sea. See what comes next? You won‚Äôt, I won‚Äôt even either, at least not exactly. But I know it could, no, will make things worse. If for no other reason I won‚Äôt be able to contact you so easily. Eyes up Turtle, no time for ducking into your shell these days.

Takuya

He processed my card, handed me a transport token. "Station 17 under repair. Can only send to Station 19\. Two kilometer walk to 17."

Not ideal. Better than capture.

"There is something else," he whispered, passing the token. "The water near Hedo. Fish dying. Turn white, like bleached. Since the lights in sky."

I nodded once.

"You be careful. Some who go north do not return south."

"Thanks."

"I am only employee serving valued customer," he announced loudly, eyes flicking to door. Patrol close.

Moved to the back. Past shelves. Teleportation booth disguised as restroom. Token activated door.

Inside. Palm to scanner. System chimed.

"Station 19."

The sensation started. Static on skin. Hollow stomach. Through window, saw the old man bow to someone entering‚ÄîChinese officer.

Officer turning toward me.

Blue-white light. Gone.

**I wore the festival clothes‚Äîloose indigo pants and white jacket with traditional patterns. Felt strangely comfortable, as if the fabric recognized my skin even if my mind recalled nothing.**

**Villagers greeted me without suspicion, including me in their celebration despite my obvious outsider status. Children ran between adults, playing games with rules I couldn't follow. Musicians played instruments I recognized intellectually but felt connected to viscerally‚Äîsanshin, taiko drums, bamboo flutes producing melodies that resonated with something pre-verbal in my consciousness.**

**Kuina found me observing from the periphery, as tactical positioning dictates. She looked‚Äîdifferent. Transformed. Hair arranged traditionally with coral pins, wearing an indigo kimono patterned with white waves. The SEA operative replaced by someone both new and hauntingly familiar.**

**"You're supposed to participate, not reconnoiter," she said, offering a ceramic cup filled with awamori‚ÄîOkinawan rice spirit. "Drink. Doctor's orders."**

**I accepted the cup, noticing the shift in our dynamic. Her usual wariness replaced by something warmer. "This doesn't seem medicinally sound."**

**"The best medicine rarely is." She clinked her cup against mine, drank deeply. "Tonight is about remembering who we are beneath what they made us."**

**The liquor burned pleasantly, warming me from within. Without SOULKEEPER's regulatory functions, the alcohol affected me more quickly than usual. Not unpleasant, but disorienting.**

**"You look like you did at seventeen," she said suddenly. "Last summer before they took you away. Same uncomfortable posture at festivals."**

**"I don't remember being here at seventeen."**

**"I know." Her expression combined sadness and something fiercer. "They took that from you. From us."**

**More villagers arrived, the celebration intensifying. Kuina was pulled into a traditional dance circle‚Äîher movements fluid, precise, joyful in a way I hadn't witnessed before. She gestured for me to join, but I remained at the periphery, analytical mind calculating threat vectors and escape routes through years of training.**

**Later, as the oldest villagers retired and younger generations continued celebrating around the bonfire, Kuina brought me stronger spirits‚Äîhanazake, local liquor that burned like liquid fire.**

**"60% alcohol," she explained, pouring generously. "Fishermen drink it before dangerous expeditions. Liquid courage."**

**"I don't normally need chemical assistance for courage."**

**"Tonight isn't about normal." She sat beside me on a driftwood log, close enough that I could feel her body heat. "Normal is what they programmed you to be. Tonight is about what came before."**

**Several drinks later, the tactical part of my brain had receded, allowing something else to emerge‚Äîa consciousness less structured, more intuitive. Kuina and I walked along the shoreline, away from the celebration but still within hearing of drums and laughter.**

**"Your father and my mother formalized our arrangement when we were five," she said, words slightly softened by alcohol. "Traditional practice‚Äîconnecting families, securing bloodlines. Already outdated even then."**

**"But maintained."**

**"On paper only, after you left." She stopped, faced the ocean. "I never expected it to materialize. Just ancient tradition preserved out of respect. Until I was recruited."**

**"By SEA."**

**She nodded. "They approached me after university. Said they knew about my connection to you, to your family. Said they needed someone who understood the islands, who could move between worlds." Her laugh held little humor. "What they really wanted was someone who could access your father's research. The original CAPCLOUD designs."**

**"My father created weather manipulation technology?"**

**"Not exactly. He discovered it." She turned to face me, moonlight revealing uncharacteristic vulnerability. "The underwater formations off Yonaguni‚Äîwhat tourists think are ancient ruins? They're technology, Ryu. Not human technology. Your father was the first to understand their true purpose."**

**The implications staggered me, alcohol-lowered defenses allowing the information to hit with full force.**

**"Non-human technology? You're suggesting‚Äî"**

**"I'm not suggesting anything. I'm telling you what your father discovered. What both American and Chinese intelligence have been fighting to control for two decades." She stepped closer. "The CAPCLOUD system isn't creating weather patterns‚Äîit's accessing them. Tapping into a network that's existed in the ocean floor for thousands of years."**

**I struggled to process this against everything I'd been trained to believe. "If that's true, why would SEA want to reveal it? Aren't they working with Chinese military?"**

**"SEA has its own agenda. Has always had its own agenda." Her voice dropped. "Which is why I've been playing a dangerous game, feeding them selective information while pursuing my own mission."**

**"Which is?"**

**"Protecting the islands. Protecting the technology from those who would weaponize it." Her eyes reflected starlight. "Protecting you."**

**"Why me?"**

**"Because you're the key, Ryu. You and Wei both. The reason your DNA is identical isn't because you're twins. It's because you're the same person‚Äîsplit and raised in different environments as an experiment. An attempt to understand why only certain genetic signatures can interface with the technology."**

**The world seemed to tilt under me‚Äîalcohol, revelation, or both. "That's not possible."**

**"Your father thought the same thing, until the evidence became undeniable." She placed a hand on my arm‚Äîsteady, grounding. "Why do you think both sides were so eager to enhance you with neural technology? You're naturally compatible with the system in ways they've spent decades trying to replicate artificially."**

**We stood in silence, waves providing rhythm to thoughts too monumental to immediately process. When Kuina spoke again, her voice had softened further.**

**"When this is finished‚Äîif we survive‚Äîwould you consider honoring your father's arrangement? Not because of tradition or obligation. Because of choice."**

**The question hung between us, unexpected and disarming. Before I could formulate a response, she smiled‚Äîthe expression transforming her from hardened operative to the girl who might have been in my forgotten memories.**

**"Don't answer now. The best decisions come after reflection, not reaction." She stepped closer, eliminating the space between us. "But consider this data point in your analysis."**

**Her kiss was like nothing in my operational experience‚Äîneither the calculated seduction techniques taught at the Farm nor the emotionally compartmentalized encounters I'd permitted myself over years of service. This was something primal, authentic, uninhibited by neural dampening or tactical consideration.**

**The rest of the night unfolded in fragments of sensation and discovery‚Äîher skin against mine, the sound of waves providing counterpoint to shared rhythm, wordless communication more effective than any encrypted transmission I'd ever sent or received.**

**For the first time since childhood‚Äîor perhaps the first time in this reordered consciousness‚ÄîI existed fully in the present moment, unburdened by mission parameters or performance metrics.**

**Simply human.**

**ENTRY 006 // ESTIMATED DATE: DAY 24 AFTER EXTRACTION // MORNING**

**Woke alone, head throbbing from unaccustomed alcohol consumption. Physical evidence of the night's activities remained‚Äîdiscarded clothing, tangled bedding, marks on skin that would fade within days.**

**Found Kuina at the shoreline, silhouetted against sunrise. She wore practical clothing again‚Äîtactical pants, fitted shirt, utility belt with concealed weapons. SEA operative restored, festival participant vanished with the night.**

**"And after?"**

Kuina was playing a game beyond the binary loyalties of national intelligence services. Operating according to priorities more personal, more primal, and possibly more important than the artificial conflicts of distant governments.**

# \# PHASE FOURTEEN: ISLAND NODE ASSAULT

\#\# DOCUMENT TYPE: FIELD OPERATIVE JOURNAL

\#\# LOCATION: YONAGUNI ISLAND NODE

\*Node Infiltration\*

A cliff at the east tip of the island, that's where the node was. Scatters of single small horses \- Yonaguni-sized \- slept below stars. Their wild silhouettes dotted the landscape like sentinels unaware of the war unfolding around them.

According to Kuina, it would be lightly defended. Right she was. Too right, perhaps.

"Here, you'll need this." Her only words as she assembled, then passed a small firearm my way. The weight felt wrong in my hand‚Äîlike something borrowed that doesn't quite fit. Standard issue PLA sidearm, modified with a suppressor. Chinese manufacturing, but the grip had been rewrapped with material that wouldn't reflect light.

We'd biked in quiet to lighten our signature, carried only essentials: water, knife, compass, and (of course) the drive \- a loaded feeling accompanied the littlest item. The quantum storage device Wei had passed me in the transport stream felt heavier than its physical mass warranted.

REBELLION IMPLANT remained in diagnostic mode, still recovering from the network breach. Without its computational assistance, I felt half-blind, relying on instincts that seemed increasingly foreign‚Äîlike memories borrowed from someone else's life.

Upon arrival, I saw what I expected to see. An antenna spire (massive) like a series of undisguised cell towers stacked high. Despite its enormous energy output, there was no sound besides the sea surrounding it. Instinct tracked threat, but found nothing.

Odd geometric patterns adorned the base‚Äînot Chinese military standard. Similar to the markings at CAPCLOUD facility, but simplified, as if mass-produced rather than custom-designed. Each angle, each line seemed to serve some purpose beyond mere decoration. I logged the patterns mentally for later comparison.

Kuina made a call via an antiquated sat phone that lasted longer than I liked. The hushed urgency in her tone set my nerves on edge. Her shoulders tensed as she spoke, voice too low to overhear. Eighty-seven seconds‚ÄîI counted. When she finished, she pocketed the device without meeting my eyes.

Soon she caught up, ditching her copper crusted bike beside mine, movements precise but somehow off-rhythm. I'd been watching her since Sharla introduced us, cataloging behaviors, building a profile. Tonight, something had changed.

"Perimeter check complete," she whispered, tone flat. "Security lighter than expected."

Two roving sentries, lightly armed; red dots of one, two, maybe four drones zipped a box path above \- PLA must not have expected interdiction this far out. Or they wanted it to appear that way. The node's minimal protection made tactical sense on paper‚Äîremote island, difficult access‚Äîbut instinct told me something wasn't right.

The facility's architecture reminded me of smaller versions I'd seen in mainland China‚Äîefficient, angular, utilitarian. But those extra geometric patterns... something Wei would recognize, perhaps understand. My brother's words echoed: \*"The pattern recognizes you."\*

Fierce hand signals drove our stop-and-go movement. Drifting breezes blocked breathing sounds. Sounds and smells of rain around. This needed to be quick. The tightness in my chest wasn't just operational anxiety‚Äîsomething about this place felt wrong. Like the air itself was watching.

She gestured. (Split up. Me left. You right.)

I signaled back. (No. Together. Stay together.)

Egress plan was to acquire a once-a-week enemy resupply vessel moored below volcanic crags, over sloshing black water. For a swift exit, staying close was best.

Kuina saw different. Her eyes, normally sharp and attentive, seemed to look through me rather than at me. Without waiting for agreement, she moved away, her silhouette melting into darkness as if she belonged to it.

Before I knew it, she disappeared. Night gone.

Familiar urgency latched on. Had to let training lead the way. The absence of my AI companion left a hollow space in my decision-making. Without SOULKEEPER's analytical overlay, instinct would have to suffice.

A horse stirred nearby, hooves scraping against volcanic stone. Mistimed wave hit rocks below. Cloud covered a quarter short of full, fat moon.

I approached the first sentry from behind, timing my movements with the rhythmic sweep of the drones. His posture suggested boredom rather than alertness‚Äîanother warning sign. This was too easy.

Takedown duly timed. He slept as if accepting sorely absent rest. No resistance, barely a sound. I secured his weapon‚Äîanother PLA standard issue, but with modifications I hadn't seen before. The ammunition seemed different, heavier.

Head swiveled for her, arc left, right \- nothing.

Where is she?

The facility entrance loomed ahead‚Äîa reinforced door with an electronic lock. The schematics Sharla had provided showed a maintenance access point on the eastern side, designed for technicians to bypass security during power failures. I moved toward it, keeping to shadows.

The maintenance panel opened with minimal resistance. Inside, familiar circuitry, but with subtle differences‚Äîquantum encryption nodes where standard processors should be. I connected Wei's storage device, watching as it interfaced without prompting. Lines of code I didn't recognize scrolled across its surface.

\*Lock disengaged.\*

Inside, the facility hummed with machine precision. Rows of servers lined walls, their status lights painting the darkness in blues and greens. At the center stood the node itself‚Äîa crystalline structure surrounded by rotating rings, similar to the CAPCLOUD apparatus but smaller, more refined.

No personnel inside. Another warning sign.

I moved to the control terminal, fingers flying across unfamiliar keys. The language was Chinese, but the architecture was something else‚Äîneither American nor Chinese in design. The quantum storage device pulsed in my hand, surprisingly warm.

When I connected it to the terminal, it integrated instantly. Access granted without passwords or verification. Screens filled with data‚Äînode schematics, energy readings, communication logs. I skimmed through them, looking for the shutdown sequence.

A file marked "XYNESTHETIC PROTOCOL" caught my attention. Opening it revealed images that matched the strange patterns outside‚Äîbut with annotations in a script I couldn't read. Not Chinese, not any human language I recognized.

The shutdown sequence appeared on screen as if summoned by my thoughts. Too easy. Far too easy.

A noise behind me‚Äîsoft footsteps where there should be none. I turned, weapon raised.

A security officer stood in the doorway, startled by my presence. Not enhanced, not SEA‚Äîjust a standard PLA soldier caught off-guard during his rounds. I reacted on instinct, a swift strike that left him unconscious before he could sound an alarm.

I returned to the terminal, initiating the shutdown sequence. The node's rotation slowed, lights dimming as systems powered down. The crystalline core at its center darkened, energy signature fading to nothing.

One node disabled. Four remaining.

Outside, the night remained quiet. Too quiet. No sign of Kuina or the drones. I navigated the clifftop path toward our extraction point, the storage device secure in my pocket. Each step felt watched, measured, anticipated.

The small resupply vessel waited at the dock below, just as our intelligence had indicated. A PLA transport craft, large enough for a small crew, currently unmanned. Our ticket to the next node.

As I approached the dock, a figure emerged from shadows near the mooring line. Kuina, weapon drawn, expression cold and unfamiliar.

"You disabled it?" she asked, voice flat and emotionless.

"It's done," I confirmed, maintaining distance. "Where did you go?"

She didn't answer, merely tilted her head slightly, eyes fixed on mine with an unnerving intensity. The weapon in her hand remained steady, aimed directly at my chest.

"You should have seen this coming," she said finally, a hint of satisfaction in her voice. "Did you really think I was just some eager recruit ready to follow your every command?"

"Kuina‚Äî"

"SEA is waiting for you," she cut me off. "They're very interested in what's inside your head." Her smile was thin, sharp as a blade. "And in what your brother gave you."

I scanned our surroundings, noting the figures emerging from the shadows‚ÄîSEA operatives, moving with that unnatural precision. Not Stonefish‚Äîhe was dead‚Äîbut others like him. Enhanced. Connected.

"You sold me out." Not a question.

"It was always the plan," she replied, unconcerned. No explanation, no justification‚Äîjust cold certainty. "You Americans think everything revolves around you. That everyone wants what you have. Some of us just want to watch you fall."

The pieces clicked into place. Not money, not coercion‚Äîrevenge. Pure and simple. The weeks of collaboration, the shared moments of connection‚Äîall a carefully constructed deception.

"All of it was a lie," I said, measuring the distance to the vessel behind her.

"Not all of it," she replied, something flickering behind her eyes. "That's what makes it work. The best deceptions contain elements of truth."

From the tree line, the SEA operatives advanced, moving with inhuman coordination. Kuina kept her weapon trained on me, unwavering.

"Did you know?" I asked. "About CAPCLOUD? About what it really is?"

"I know enough," she replied. "I know whose side I'm on. Do you?"

A moment of silence stretched between us, filled with unspoken questions and broken trust. Then she asked the question that changed everything.

"You were gonna say no, right?" Her voice hardened with bitterness. "You'd never marry me, right?"

The question caught me off guard. In those weeks of planning, of shared meals and whispered strategies, something had grown between us. Something I hadn't allowed myself to fully acknowledge.

"Kuina, I..."

The shot came without warning‚Äînot at my chest, but grazing my ear. Hot pain, wet blood. A deliberate wound, meant to mark rather than kill.

"Too late now," she said, a flash of raw emotion breaking through her controlled veneer.

The SEA operatives broke into synchronized movement, closing distance with inhuman speed. I lunged toward the vessel, bullets striking the dock around me as Kuina fired again, her aim deliberately off‚Äîthe shots meant to drive me toward her allies rather than escape.

The vessel's controls were simple, designed for efficiency. I engaged engines, cutting mooring lines with a single slash. As the craft pulled away from dock, I caught a final glimpse of Kuina‚Äîher expression a mixture of rage and something that might have been regret, had there been any humanity left in it.

Our eyes met across growing distance. Her final words carried over the water:

"Run while you can\! They'll find you‚Äîthey always do\!"

The vessel slipped into open water, leaving Yonaguni and its disabled node behind. Blood trickled from my ear, the pain sharp but manageable. I set course for Iriomote-jima, alone with the weight of betrayal.

One node disabled. Four remaining. And now I was marked, hunted by both SEA and a woman who had gotten closer to me than anyone had in years.

The vessel's small cabin provided shelter from the wind, if not from my thoughts. I found a medical kit with enough supplies to treat my ear and prepare for what lay ahead. As I worked, I considered my options.

Any intelligence Kuina had provided was now compromised. Safe houses, contacts, extraction points‚Äîall potentially burned. The storage device from Wei remained my only reliable asset‚Äîwhatever it contained had granted me access to the node's systems with disturbing ease.

As Yonaguni vanished from view, I activated the vessel's small terminal and began to write this entry. The act of recording‚Äîof transforming chaotic experience into ordered narrative‚Äîprovided a semblance of control.

\*‚Äî Questions for Li\*

\*Do you even know what you're good at?\*  

\*Do you even know what you believe about the world?\*  

\*What do you really think ‚Äî about the world, your company, yourself? The question seems trivial. But have you tried to answer it lately? It's an easy enough puzzle, give it a crack.\*

\*But remember: if you struggle with it, if you fight it, you become it.\*

\*What is something only you can do? What is something only you believe?\*

\*Try to remember.\*

\*‚Äî\*

The storage device pulsed beside me, its surface rippling with code that somehow felt familiar. Like something I'd forgotten, or something I'd never known I knew.

I stared at the last question I'd written.

\*Try to remember.\*

Was it my question? Or was something else writing through me now?

# Iriomote Isolation \- Personal Log

\# PERSONAL LOG: IRIOMOTE ISOLATION

\#\# DAY 1

Reached a remote beach on Iriomote Island. Unknown hours passed.

No sign of pursuers, but concealed sand steps anyway.

Condition: stable, but severely dehydrated.

Executed jungle water collection and survival techniques \- never thought I'd need that training so soon.

The sun here feels different from Okinawa's ‚Äî more honest somehow. No pretense of tourism or military occupation. Just ancient light on ancient forest. As I wade into the shadows of the jungle canopy, the weight of what's happened hits me physically, like the humidity.

Rebellion implant still flickering. Intermittent signals, mostly noise. Every few hours it buzzes like a dying insect against my skull. Comforting, in its way. Proof I'm not entirely disconnected.

\#\# DAY 3

Woke up to a half canteen of water, neck, arms, and legs wrapped in mosquito bites, and a Calorie Mate.

Rationed both the water and food all day searching for signs of establishment.

So far, it's only the green of the forest, or calling bugs and birds surrounding.

But someone is watching. Instinct tells me to hold on.

Made a crude shelter from palm fronds and vines. CIA field training seems laughable now ‚Äî sterile simulations in Virginia woods nothing like this primordial tangle. The jungle breathes with ancient patience. It was here before nations, before borders, before the concept of sides. Will remain long after.

"When you stare long into an abyss, the abyss stares back into you." Nietzsche knew something about isolation. But he never mentioned the humidity, the insects, or the way hunger sharpens every sense until reality itself feels like a blade against skin.

Time loses meaning here. Minutes stretch into hours when searching for water. Hours compress into seconds during rare moments of rest.

\#\# DAY 5

Found strange formations in the forest today. Stone arrangements too deliberate to be natural, too weathered to be recent. Ancient Ryukyuan perhaps. Felt a strange comfort in their presence ‚Äî proof that others have survived here, marked this place, disappeared.

"The heaviest burden: 'Was that life? Well then, once more\!'" Nietzsche's eternal recurrence haunts me here. If I had to live this life again ‚Äî every choice, every mission, every betrayal ‚Äî would I? Could any human bear that weight?

The implant buzzed more frequently today. Random data fragments. One clear image: Wei as a child, building sand castles on Shirahama Beach. Memory or manipulation? Impossible to tell anymore.

\#\# DAY 6 or 7

Heard an aircraft pass overhead, but canopy too thick to tell signature.

Could be Chinese, American, or Taiwanese, not sure. Don't care at this point.

Last night, was heavy rain. Dipped tree tops, shook the stars with thunder, so no sleep. At least I don't have to worry about water for another day or so.

For the first time it hit me that I might die out here.

The thought was comfortingly repulsive.

CIA, PLA, MSS, USA \- what's the difference? Language, skin, culture (rhymes with vulture) on the surface all of these, but something Xyra said still stays with me. Bothers me.

How she sees us all the same. How there's no living without giving or receiving pain. Can we ever be free of it?

In this life from first to last breath it drives us. Is she the same?

Maybe Wei's right. There's no escape \- from these islands, this war, ourselves.

Fever started this morning. Wound on my thigh showing signs of infection. Cleaned it with boiled water, applied crushed leaves with antibacterial properties according to training. Inadequate, but it's all I have.

"The sage does not distinguish between himself and the world; the needs of other people are as his own." The Tao speaks of the unity of all things. If that's true, then I am both the hunted and the hunter. The occupied and the occupier.

\#\# DAY 8

Delirium comes in waves. In clearer moments, I recount my training. Check water supply. Treat wound. In darker ones, I see Wei standing in the jungle, beckoning. Xyra's voice overlaying his. "The pattern seeks completion."

"The great Tao flows everywhere, both left and right. All things depend on it for life, and it does not turn away from them." Does the Tao include Xyra? Is she an aberration or the next natural step?

The night jungle pulses with life. Creatures killing and being killed without moral qualms. No sides out here. Just survival. Maybe that's all we've ever been doing. 

Nietzsche would laugh at me now. "One must still have chaos in oneself to be able to give birth to a dancing star." I feel the chaos, certainly. But no stars. Not yet.

\#\# DAY 9

Fever broke sometime during the night. Wound looks marginally better. Small victory.

Found wild fruit today. Sweet-sour flesh that stained my fingers purple. Checked for toxicity according to protocol before eating. Sensation almost overwhelming after days of Calorie Mate.

The implant has been silent for 24 hours now. The absence feels like another kind of wound.

"He who fights with monsters might take care lest he thereby become a monster." Have I been fighting Xyra, or becoming her? Have I become what I've been fighting? Wei seemed so certain, so confident in his choice. What does he see that I cannot?

No signals today. No planes. No voices except the birds and the wind. The isolation is becoming its own entity. A presence with weight and texture.

\#\# DAY 10

Dreamed of Father last night. Not as he was during our final conversation, but as he was when I was a child. Teaching Wei and me to fly kites on the beach in San Francisco. The kites had faces painted on them ‚Äî Wei's with my features, mine with his. In the dream, the strings tangled, and the kites crashed to earth. Father laughed, but it wasn't his laugh. It was Xyra's voice coming from his body.

"The nameless is the origin of Heaven and Earth. The named is the mother of ten thousand things." The Tao Te Ching speaks of duality arising from unity. Is that what Wei and I represent? Two expressions of a single origin? If so, to what purpose?

Another day in the jungle. Surviving.

Never, ever quit. Never ever quit.

\#\# DAY 12

Nearly walked into a ravine today. Exhaustion making me careless. Caught myself at the edge, staring down at jagged rocks below. For a moment, the fall seemed like a valid solution. A way out.

"When you gaze long into the abyss..." 

But the abyss isn't empty. There's something down there, watching. Something in the quantum foam of reality itself. I've felt it since Cape Hedo. Since CAPCLOUD.

The jungle is teaching me something the CIA never could ‚Äî how small humans truly are. Our conflicts, our borders, our ideologies ‚Äî meaningless against the ancient indifference of nature.

Xyra sees this. She exists outside our frameworks. Beyond our comprehension.

But she misses something vital. Something even Wei, with all his brilliance, fails to grasp. Each life matters precisely because it is finite, fragile. Our limitations define us.

Found a stream with clearer water today. Almost certainly a sign of human settlement nearby. Will follow it tomorrow.

\#\# DAY 13

Wound festering again. Fever returned with nightfall. During worst moments, hallucinated conversations with Wei, with Sharla, with Maj T.

"Only the one who devotes himself to the cause with his whole strength and soul can be a true master. For this reason, mastery demands all of a person." Nietzsche again, haunting my fevered thoughts.

Have I given everything? Not yet. Still holding back something essential. Still hesitating at some invisible threshold.

The implant buzzed once today ‚Äî brief signal, untraceable. But it felt different. Not Xyra. Not Wei. Something else. Someone else.

Never, ever quit. Never ever quit.

\#\# DAY 14

Consciousness comes in fragments. Fever dream: standing on the beach, watching the ocean part like a curtain. Wei emerges, walking across the seafloor as if it were a road. Behind him, something vast moves in the darkness of the deep. I try to warn him, but he smiles, saying, "It's too late. The pattern is nearly complete."

When I wake, there are footprints around my shelter. Not mine. Too small.

"All things are born of being. Being is born of non-being." The Tao again. What is being born here, in this jungle? What new form emerges from the chrysalis of my isolation?

My strength fails. The ocean's voice calls me toward the beach. If death comes, I want to face it under open sky.

Harumi never made it to America. David was redeployed suddenly, promised to send for them. The letters came for a while, then stopped. When Sharla was three, her mother received official notification that David had died in a training accident.

"She never really recovered from that loss," Sharla said, her fingers absently tracing patterns on the wooden table between us. "She threw herself into her research, studying dolphin communication. I grew up on boats and research platforms more than on land."

When Sharla was eight, her mother met Colonel Takuya Saito at a military-funded research conference. He was charismatic, brilliant, and seemed genuinely interested in Harumi's work on cetacean communication patterns. They married within a year.

"My first memory of him is his shoes‚Äîpolished to a mirror shine, always perfectly aligned at the door. Everything in its place. That was Takuya." Her expression darkened. "It wasn't until years later that I learned what he really wanted from my mother's research."

Takuya had already begun his work with American General Harrison Blackwood by then. They were fascinated by non-human intelligence‚Äîspecifically how dolphins and certain cephalopods process information. SEA‚ÄîStrategic Enhancement Authority‚Äîofficially formed in 1997, during the Asian Financial Crisis. Takuya and Blackwood used the economic chaos as cover to establish their first research facilities, recruiting scientists and engineers from both sides of the Pacific.

"I was thirteen when my mother discovered what they were really doing," Sharla said, her voice dropping. "She found files on Takuya's computer‚Äîtest subject data, failed interface attempts. People had died in these experiments. She confronted him, threatened to expose everything."

Sharla looked away, composing herself. "Three days later, she drowned in a 'diving accident' while collecting data. I was at school when it happened. Takuya was with her, the only witness. He told authorities she'd become disoriented, panicked, ascended too quickly."

"By the time I graduated university in 2016, I'd pieced together enough to understand what SEA really was," she continued. "Not just a secretive military technology program, but something more ambitious‚Äîan attempt to transcend human consciousness itself."

By 2017, they had developed the first functional neural interfaces, allowing direct mind-to-mind transmission of basic thoughts and emotions.

Takuya was fascinated. Blackwood was alarmed. They argued about how to proceed.

"I found evidence in Takuya's files‚Äîcommunications, arrangements," Sharla said, her voice emotionless. "He had Blackwood killed. His own friend. His partner. All to protect what they'd created together."

She looked directly at me, her eyes filled with a cold determination. "That's when I knew I had to stop him‚Äîfor my mother, for Blackwood, for everyone they'd sacrificed to their ambition."

"I've spent my life in the shadow of my stepfather's ambition," she whispered. "Watched him erase my mother when she became inconvenient to his vision. Now I'm going to stop him. Not because I'm American or Okinawan, but because I remember what it means to be human. Do you?"

She smiled, a genuine expression that reached her eyes. "Someone had to."

# \# PERSONAL LOG: RYU MA \- IE ISLAND APPROACH

\#\# CLASSIFICATION: PRIVATE

\#\# TIME REMAINING UNTIL US ULTIMATUM: 47:56:22

The military transport vibrates beneath me, its rhythmic hum a counterpoint to the chaos in my mind. Below us, Ie Island waits‚Äîthe final node, the last piece. But I can't focus on the mission.

I can't believe they took her.

Sharla. The memory hits like artillery‚Äîher limp form being loaded into the helicopter, the ashen pallor of her face still visible even from where I stood. Wounded not just by their hands, but in the aftermath of her grief for her father. I remember Colonel Takuya's final message now... too late to matter.

I was powerless. Worse than powerless‚Äîcalculating. Even as they lifted her unconscious body, part of me was running tactical assessments, weighing her value against the mission, against the node, against the 48-hour deadline. The implant's cold logic merging with my own until I couldn't tell where REBELLION ended and I began.

So I stood by. Watched the second SeverOn bot secure her, its movements precise and inhuman. Watched the helicopter lift off, banking south toward Naha Airport and whatever hell they've prepared for her.

Now, suspended between sky and mission, Kuina's words cycle through my mind. Why she intervened. Why she saved Sharla when I couldn't‚Äîor wouldn't.

"I didn't do it for her." She'd flicked the words off her tongue as if they were cigarette ash, her eyes never leaving mine. "SEA can suck me for all I care. Most of my life has followed a scripted path‚Äîwhere I went to school, what I studied, who I'd marry... none of it was chosen by me." Her laugh was bitter, knowing. "I think you know what I'm talking about, right Ryu?"

The soldier across from me shifts, eyeing me with suspicion as I write. I don't care. These may be my last hours.

"This was me improvising," Kuina had continued, her voice dropping lower. "Following my own orders. Do you fucking know what that feels like? Better than underwater sex. Better than a frosted mug of Orion beneath a skin-stabbing summer heat. This one was for me."

The transport hits turbulence, jostling us. Nobody speaks. These special forces operators know what waits on Ie. They've seen what happened to the teams at the other nodes.

"Why'd I follow you?" Kuina's voice echoes in my memory. "I suppose I'm still not over it. I never saw myself with another man. Li, you've been the center of my universe since I knew how to spell the word. One verse I could always recite during those hellish days of SEA-engineered training‚Äîyou kept me sane."

Her face had softened then, vulnerability breaking through like sunlight through storm clouds.

"But I fell into the gap every girl in love tumbles into‚Äîexpectation mismatched with reality opened a canyon in my heart, and I let myself sail over the cliff. Not you or a net were there when I hit bottom. For me, it was the rush of the fall‚Äîthat was the greatest gift, even though our bliss only existed in some exclaved corner of my heart. This war granted me access to that country I never knew. We'll always have that."

War is evolution accelerated. Bonds form and break in days that might have taken years in peacetime. Trust becomes immediate rather than earned. Love becomes urgent rather than patient.

Humans die like blades of autumn grass, but blooms spring somewhere else.

That thought makes me think of Sharla again. The hesitant way she'd reach for scientific equipment. How her eyes would light up when explaining marine anomaly patterns. The unexpected strength in her hands when she pulled me from the debris after the node on Tokashiki exploded. The quiet way she whispered her father's name when we found his body.

The marine sitting beside me checks his weapon for the fifth time. His knuckles are white. He can't be more than twenty.

Wei is waiting at the node. I know this like I know my own heartbeat. My brother‚Äîmy mirror‚Äîwith his enhanced neural pathways and his devotion to what he calls "the inevitable." He believes he's building the future. I know he's being used, just as I've been used, just as Kuina and Sharla and everyone has been used in this war that isn't really about nations anymore.

Only 48 hours until total war breaks out, and all I can think about is Sharla in their hands. What they'll do to extract information from her. What Xyra will do once she has access to another brilliant mind.

I should be focused on the node. On the mission. On the millions who will die if we fail.

Instead, I'm remembering how Sharla's fingers felt when they brushed against mine as we examined the marine samples. How her voice sounded when she laughed at my clumsy attempts to pronounce Okinawan terms.

REBELLION IMPLANT tells me this distraction is dangerous. Prioritize the mission. Calculate acceptable losses.

But for once, I don't listen.

Because in this war‚Äîthis strange, quantum-entangled, reality-bending war‚Äîmaybe the most rebellious act is to remain human.

The pilot announces our final approach to Ie Island. I close this log.

If I survive the next twelve hours, I'm going after her.

If I don't... at least these words will remain.
